definition: to break away/to extricate/to escape/to leave the confines of
to shed/to take off/to escape/to get away from

to go out/to come out/to occur/to produce/to go beyond/to rise/to put forth/to happen/(used after a verb to indicate an outward direction or a positive result)/classifier for dramas, plays, operas etc

sentences.english: We need to stop letting our Congress and the President get away withthe crimes their getting away with.
sentences.chinese: 不要再讓國會和總統逃脫出他們該受到的制裁。

sentences.english: Old pitons should not be reused once they fall out.
sentences.chinese: 老舊的巖釘一旦脫出之後，就不得重新加以使用。

sentences.english: He had won his first release from the fences of home.
sentences.chinese: 他第一次成功地脫出家庭的樊籠。

sentences.english: Objective To evaluate treatment of the bleeding and prolapse of hemorrhoids by copper ion electrochemistry.
sentences.chinese: 目的利用銅離子電化學療法治療痔出血及痔脫出。

sentences.english: Sometimes external hemorrhoids prolapse, or anal penetration is now outside.
sentences.chinese: 外痔有時會脫出或突現於肛管口外。

sentences.english: I slip my arm out from under his sleep head.
sentences.chinese: 我從他沈睡的頭顱脫出手臂。

sentences.english: How this can be done depends on the circumstances.
sentences.chinese: 如何脫出法，須依情況而定。

sentences.english: They could have escaped right out of a Jane Austen novel.
sentences.chinese: 他們可以逃脫出一個簡奧斯汀的小說。

sentences.english: The release of infectious nuclear acid from the viral coat is called uncoating.
sentences.chinese: 病毒的感染性核酸從外殼中脫出，叫做脫殼。

definition: lit. to scratch the outside of the boot (idiom)/fig. beside the point/ineffectual
(of a person) sad beyond words (idiom)/(of music, literature etc) poignant/very sentimental
different routes to the same destination (idiom); fig. different means of achieve the same end
lit. draw legs on a snake (idiom); fig. to ruin the effect by adding sth superfluous/to overdo it
to move/to shift/to move out of the way/to divert (money etc) to a different purpose
to have a fluent command of (idiom)
lit. as round as pearls and as smooth as jade (idiom)/fig. elegant and polished (of singing or writing)
to lie in disarray/to cut across/to traverse
to spin a web (spider)/to weave a net (e.g. for fishing)
